Content: Youth hockey decisions are expensive and confusing. Most of what families need to make them — real experiences, honest information about teams and coaches — is scattered across texts, group chats, and word of mouth. We're in a foundational phase of building transparency for parents. Profiles, events, facilities, and schools in one place. No hype, no pressure. Just clarity. If this is useful to your family, free accounts are open at myhockeyrecruiting.com

Youth hockey decisions are expensive. And most of what families need to make them isn't easy to find. We're building transparency for parents — profiles, events, facilities, schools. Foundational phase. Free accounts open. Link in bio.

The most important information in youth hockey is rarely public. Which coaches develop players well. Which programs are worth the cost. What other families actually experienced. That gap creates stress. Parents fill it with guessing. The antidote isn't more hype. It's more transparency. If you want clarity for your family, we're here.
The best info in youth hockey usually stays private. Coaches, programs, real experiences — most parents are guessing. Transparency helps. Calm, grounded, no hype. Link in bio.

Most parents are guessing when it comes to youth hockey tryouts. What to expect. How to prepare. What happens after. Our guide breaks down the basics: what to ask, what to watch for, and how to support your child through the process. No drama, no fear-mongering. Just clarity. If this resonated, pass it to another hockey parent. Full post: [link]
Youth hockey tryouts: most parents are guessing. What to expect, how to prepare, what happens after. We put together a calm, practical guide. Link in bio.

Youth hockey can feel like a maze. Different levels, different costs, different politics. It's hard to know if you're making the right call. Informed decisions come from real information — not pressure, not urgency. This is for parents who want clarity. Free accounts are open.
Youth hockey = maze. Levels, costs, politics. Hard to know if you're making the right call. Clarity helps. No pressure. Link in bio.

AAA vs AA hockey — the labels sound simple. The reality is anything but. Different regions, different expectations, different costs. We broke down what the tiers actually mean and when each might be the right fit. Not "which is better" but "what makes sense for your family." Read the full post: [link]. If it helps, share with another hockey parent.
AAA vs AA — labels sound simple. Reality isn't. Different regions, expectations, costs. We explain what the tiers mean and when each fits. Link in bio.

Parents are told to "trust the process." But what process? Who's driving it? And what does your family actually need? Clarity reduces anxiety. Not by promising outcomes, but by making the landscape visible. If you're tired of guessing, we're here.
"Trust the process" — but what process? Who's driving it? Clarity helps. Not promises, just visibility. Link in bio.

The cost of youth hockey is rarely discussed openly. Families find out piece by piece — equipment, ice time, travel, tryout fees. No one wants to be surprised. Or to feel like they're spending blindly. Transparency around costs helps families plan and decide. That's part of what we're building. Free accounts open.
Cost of youth hockey? Rarely discussed openly. Families find out piece by piece. Transparency helps. Plan, decide, reduce surprises. Link in bio.

Youth hockey levels can feel like a secret code. U8, U10, U12. Tier 1, Tier 2. Every region does it slightly differently. The goal isn't to memorize labels.
